p: Researchers consistently report that chronic HEV infections lead to a rapid cirrhosis, especially in kidney transplantation setting [ 109, 110]. It is therefore of paramount importance to treat chronic HEV infections lest cirrhosis occurs. Therapeutic options for chronic HEV infection in renal transplant recipients is not widely studied and reducing immunosuppressive drugs may be the best possible therapy [ 109] as a reduction of immunosuppression has shown to cause viral clearance. However, after reducing immunosuppression, patient progress must be monitored closely to circumvent the danger of acute rejection [ 111]. Interferon-Î± therapy recommended after other transplants can have adverse effects and high incidence of renal transplant rejection [ 109].
